def.dt: :feeling or showing no fear :not afraid He was a brave [=courageous, fearless] soldier. She gave us a brave smile. He lost his brave fight against the disease. She tried to put on/up a brave face/front [=she tried to appear brave or calm] despite the pain of the injury.
:brave people the home of the brave

utxt.vi: He smiled bravely as he stepped in front of the cameras.

def.dt: :to face or deal with (something dangerous or unpleasant) We braved [=went out in] the rain without our umbrellas. Thousands of fans braved rush-hour traffic to see the concert. I had to brave the elements [=go out in bad weather] to get to work.

:a situation or area of activity that is created by the development of something completely new and different The company was slow to enter the brave new world of computer technology. often used to suggest that something is both new and possibly dangerous Are we ready to face the brave new world of human cloning?
